talk.start.para: - (By leave).- I find that on Thursday last the Minister for Defence, in making an explanation in regard to a question asked by me, is re- . ported to have said -

quote.para: Obviously either Senator Gardiner's question was not correctly reported, or I misunderstood its purport. I have consulted the Hansard authorities, and am informed that the question, as attributed in the report to Senator Gardiner, has not been altered by him.

speech.para: I wish to say not only that I did not alter that question, but I never do alter the report of questions or remarks of mine. I apprehended at the time the Minister gave his answer that he had misunderstood my question, but I did not wish to further interfere with the business, and did not proceed further with the matter. I desire now to remove from the Minister's mind any idea that my question was misreported. Had it been answered it would have enabled the Minister for Defence to have made a more complete statement of the intentions of the Government instead of leaving the matter, as his reply to Senator Fairbairn's question left it, in such a way as possibly to convey to the minds of the public, as it did to my mind, a wrong impression. I wish to add that not only was my question properly reported and the report unaltered by me, but I believed at the time that the question was misunderstood, and turning to an honorable senator alongside of me, I remarked, " I believe that Senator Pearce has made a mistake."

talk.start.para: . - I move -

talk.start.para: - Are we expected to consider these amendments without having them before us?

- They have been distributed. No one knows more than myself how difficult it is to grasp the effect of an amendment, especially when it is an amendment upon an amendment. If at any stage the Committee desire a little further time to consider an amendment I shall willingly agree to a postponement, but most of the proposals of another place are so simple that that is hardly likely to become necessary.
- Are you accepting these amendments?

- I am accepting some of them, but alterations have been inserted in another place, as in this case, for purposes which, I am sure, will appeal to the Senate. The clause, as passed by the Senate, widened the power of the Repatriation Department with regard to returning to Australia soldiers' wives who, for some reason, might be in the Old Country. It was found that the clause did not sufficiently include sailors, and the purpose of the amendment of another place is to make it clear that the sailor shall be entitled to those benefits which the Senate said should apply to the soldier.

speech.para: Motion agreed to.
House of Representatives' Amendment. - Leave out sub-paragraph (iii) of paragraph (d) and insert-

item.label: (iii)
item.para: to the mothers of deceased or incapacitated Australian soldiers -

item.label: (a)
item.para: who are widows and were, prior to the enlistment of those soldiers, dependent upon them, or

item.label: (b)
item.para: whose husbands are so incapacitated as to be unable to contribute materially to their support.

talk.start.para: - Will the Minister explain the effect of this amendment?
. - I move -

quote.para: That the amendment be amended by leaving out the word " to " in the first line, and agreed to.

speech.para: The word " to '' is redundant. The Senate agreed in the Bill as passed to extend the benefits of the Repatriation Act to the widows of deceased soldiers who were dependent upon them, but there is another class of soldiers' mother who is equally entitled to our consideration - the woman who, though not a widow, has an incapacitated husband. It is merely necessary to state that case to insure its inclusion in the Bill.

talk.start.para: - What is the position of the soldier's father who is totally incapacitated ?
- This meets the case of the wife of that man.

- But what about a case such as I know of? A soldier makes an allotment to his mother, goes to the Front, and is killed. While he is absent his mother dies, and his father is incapacitated from earning his livelihood.
- Does the honorable senator desire to put incapacitated fathers in the same position as mothers?
- 'I think it ought to be clone.

- It is not covered by this amendment. The Senate will agree to include a woman who has a husband so incapacitated that he is not only no help, but, to some extent, a handicap to her in the battle of life. The amendment puts her in the same position as widowed mothers whose husbands are incapacitated. Senator Bakhap's suggestion is open to consideration, but it opens up the very wide question whether all the relatives of the soldier are entitled to be included in the scope of the scheme. I would ask the Committee to think very seriously before doing that. This is the very door through which crept all the abuses which have marked the American pension system. While individual cases appeal to our sympathies, I ask Senator Bakhap to let the measure remain with the present liberal amendments, until in the light of experience we see that further amendment is necessary.

. - I recognise that in dealing with amendments between the Houses it is difficult to induce the Government or the Senate to accept alterations that mean an alteration of principle, but I appeal to the Minister to see if he cannot draft this clause so widely that every 5754 Australian Soldiers' [SENATE. ] Repatriation Bill(No. 2). case of real hardship to mother and father or dependant can be met. Take the case of two men doing their share in this war. One is a soldier who heard Che call to the colours, and immediately enlisted. Perhaps I can better explain what I mean by an illustration. I was in the town of Scone the other day, and a gentleman was pointed out to me who had put £100,000 in the war loan - quite a creditable thing to have done. I am making no complaint of that, but before I left that town I met two men driving out in a sulky to a shearing shed. The younger one opened his shirt, pulled down his collar, and showed me the marks of shrapnel wounds all round his neck. I could not help contrasting what Australia had done for those two different cases. The man who had. put £100,000 into the war loan would draw £4,500 a year in interest free from taxation for the whole currency of the loan in return for what he had done.
- For which he can thank you as well as any one else.

- Exactly. I am not complaining of the man getting that return for his bit, but we ought to be very careful to see that those who have taken greater risks do not have cause to draw contrasts. The other man was so badly wounded' that though he was quite fit for work again and anxious to return to the Front, the doctors would not let him. He was going up to work as a shearer, to earn something. For every pair of boots he buys at £1 he pays 5s. duty, and for every suit of clothes he buys he pays25 per cent. duty, while when he wants a smoke he pays 4s. in the pound weight of tobacco, and that money will go to pay the interest to the man who put £100,000 into the loan to buy clothing food, and equipment for him while he was fighting.
- That is what you were saying at the by-election in New South Wales the other day. I read it word fo word.

- Exactly. It is much easier to speak when one has something prepared, and it is much better reported here, and secures much wider publicity in Hansard, because the newspapers do not report one fully. The point I want to mention is that no one raises a voice against the man who puts £100,000 into war loans and secures interest for it. If we deal so generously with wealth, we should be quite as generous towards men who have fought for us. I will give the Committee particulars of a case that is not provided for under this measure.
- The last case is provided for.

- I do not think the case I am about to mention is covered by the Bill. I refer to the father of two lads who went to the Front. One was killed, and the other, upon his return, got married. The father is now too old to work, and the young man who returned is not able to earn enough to meet all the needs of the family. Will the Bill meet a case like that ? If it does not, it should. I know that the Minister has as much sympathy with these matters as any other honorable senator, but I maintain that cases of real hardship like this are calculated to make men think there is something unfair in the measure. The Bill should be so drafted as to leave no case of real hardship in regard to dependants of our soldier unprovided for. It is the duty of the Ministry to see that this is done. It is not the duty of the Opposition to suggest, or oppose, or fight for any particular phase of the. Bill. In this matter I am following the excellent example set by Senator Millen himself in regard to war measures when he was in Opposition, and resting the responsibility upon the Government, criticising them, of course, when necessary, but not unduly interfering with them, or unduly taking up the time of the Senate.I therefore appeal to the Minister to see that the measure, when it finally leaves the Senate, provides for every legitimate case of hardship in regard to our soldiers' dependants, not classifying any particular section. I suggest that the Minister should, if necessary, adjourn the debate to allow of time to so frame a clause that it will represent perfectly the desires of the community toward our returned soldiers.
. - I understand that the clause now under consideration deals with the mothers of soldiers who have been to the Front.
- Widows or mothers' with incapacitated husbands.
- I should like to know, then, what would happen in the case of a mother who has never been married?
- An ex-nuptial child is treated ordinarily, and an unmarried wife, although not expressly provided for in the Bill, will, by my Department, be regarded as a wife.

. - I should like to draw the attention of the Minister (Senator Millen) to the case I alluded to a few moments ago, by way of interjection. His is a new portfolio, and in connexion with this measure, for which he has been particularly responsible, I took up the attitude that, as he had given a good deal of study to the subject, and probably knew a great deal more about it than any other honorable senator, it was my duty, seeing that it was largely a machinery Bill in the first instance, to give the measure a trial. I do. not think I intervened either in the debate on the second reading or-
- Order! I ask the honorable senator not to make a second-reading speech. He is now dealing with the general principles of the Bill.

- There are other phases of the particular amendment now before the Committee to be considered, and I desire to give particulars of a case which I "have in mind, without mentioning names. The father of a soldier who went to the Front was really incapacitated before his son went. This young joan was the eldest in the family, which included several young children, and the mother was having a hard struggle, even with the assistance of the eldest son, to keep things together on a kind of bush farm. This young fellow, like a brave man, enlisted, went to the Front, and, unfortunately, lost his life in battle. I had considerable difficulty in connexion with some financial considerations which had to be shown to the mother after the soldier had embarked, and I point out that since the death of this soldier the mother has died, leaving the incapacitated father and several small children to struggle on as best they can on their bush holding. In a case like this, the incapacity of the father is the real reason for giving consideration to the mother while she is alive, and if she dies, the family is handicapped to a much greater extent; so there is additional reason for consideration being shown to the incapacitated father. I respectfully suggest, therefore that an amendment should be drafted to meet cases like this, and without opening the door too wide, to place an incapacitated father of a soldier in the same position as a mother with a«n incapacitated husband.
- Why not include sisters and brothers ?
- I am not prepared to discuss that.
- I presume the honorable senator means an incapacitated father dependent upon a son who has enlisted.
- Yes. The incapacity of a father is a reason for showing consideration to a mother if the son who has enlisted has been incapacitated or has lost his life in battle.
- If the honorable senator will link up incapacity and dependants the position might be met.
- I respectfully suggest that the amendment from the other, place provides an opportunity to include incapacitated fathers in the scheme of relief.
- Is there no relief under the present position ?
- I understand there is not.
- Not if the mother dies.
- I know of a similar case myself.
- I have hastily drafted an amendment which, I think, might be suitable, namely, to add the following as a new sub-paragraph : -

quote.para: The fathers of deceased or incapacitated soldiers who are so incapacitated as to be unable to support themselves

talk.start.para: - -That does not include the condition of dependency, which I regard as important.
- In a most friendly way, then, I suggest that the Minister, because of his superior knowledge, should be able to overcome the difficulty more readily than I can on the spur of the moment.
- In any case assistance is discretionary under this clause.

- The incapacity of a father, as I have already pointed out, is the reason for consideration being shown to a mother, and if she dies there is all the more reason why the family should receive consideration, because, 5756 Australian Soldiers' [SENATE.] Repatriation Bill (No. 2). while alive, she may have been a woman of resource, and may have been able to do a good deal towards the maintenance of the family.
. - With the permission of the Committee, I move -

speech.para: That consideration of the amendment be postponed.
That will enable me, possibly, to place in a more completed form an amendment embodying the suggestion of the honorable senator.

talk.start.para: . - May I suggest also that the Minister, in dealing with the point raised by Senator Bakhap, take into consideration at the same time some such amendment as, " Provided that nothing in the Bill shall prevent the Minister from dealing with any case of hardship and from giving relief to either the parents or the dependants of any soldier " ?

speech.para: Motion agreed to; amendment postponed.

The insertion of the words, " Australian soldier " will cover both soldier and sailor, since the definition clause sets out that " soldier " includes " sailor."

This is really a verbal amendment in the sense that it is designed to set out more clearly the principle agreed to in the original measure. It is necessary that there should be some central controlling authority over the various efforts to solicit public subscriptions. It will be remembered that there was a general demand for that at the time of the consideration of the original Arbitration Bill. It was thought that, by centering the authority in the trustees who were appointed under the Bill, and, through them, in the State War Councils, that would be providing

speech.para: Australian Soldiers' [12 June, 1918.] Repatriation Bill (No. 2). 5757 necessary safeguards. The authority has now been transferred to the State Boards, but the words used in the Arbitration Act are not considered sufficiently embracing.

talk.start.para: . - Can the Minister (Senator Millen) inform me whether it is considered desirable to close up any of the funds which have been doing good work practically since the commencement of the war ? Is the amendment intended only to control those funds so that, under fair conditions, the patriotic people interested could always secure permission to carry on their activities as hitherto? My reason for putting the position in that way is that I have great fears that a specific organization, which has been doing good work, if it is not permitted to augment its funds in the manner in which it has been accustomed, may have to cease operations. I ask the Minister to give me an assurance that there is no intention to do anything of that character whatever.

. - I can give the honorable senator no assurance as to any particular fund. Authority rests with the State Boards, but it is not intended that there shall be any restriction upon legitimate effort. That which I assume was in the minds of members of Parliament when the original section' was passed was that it was necessary to have some authority which, for example, would prevent a clash of dates upon which various patriotic efforts might be undertaken. We all know of instances where it was clear that the exercise of some controlling authority was necessary, if only for the protection of the public, and to prevent that leakage which is almost bound to occur when efforts promoted for the best purposes are not properly organized. But the question of the continued operations of any. body rests with the State Boards, and I do not expect that those authorities would exercise their powers in an arbitrary manner.

. - I accept the assurance of the Minister, and will take the opportunity of interviewing him privately, when I shall try to show him that something has been done which, in my opinion, has not been quite legitimate. I can only assure the Minister that every individual connected with the association that I have in mind has been a keen voluntary worker. All activities have been entirely honorary, and, indeed, many of those connected with it have almost impoverished themselves in their efforts to keep up the fund in question.
- I will be glad to confer with the honorable senator.

. - I do not know whether this is the proper place to raise the matters to which I wish to refer, but I direct the attention of the Minister for Repatriation (Senator Millen) to the fact that in South Australia provision has been made for grants for homes for soldiers and their relatives. Until recently it was the practice to make a grant of £675 for the purchase of a home, but latterly the grant has been reduced by £75, and is now fixed at £600. The deduction of the £75 in many cases makes all the difference between procuring a home for the soldier and his relatives and not procuring one. We are all aware that at the present time nothing much in the way of a home can be procured for £600 in any part contiguous to the city where workmen have to live. I ask the Minister whether he will see that the allowance for those desiring to procure a home shall be restored to £675.

speech.para: Another matter to which I wish to refer is that returned soldiers have been in the past allowed a sum of £25 for the purchase of furniture, when they take up housekeeping again. I understand that this allowance has been discontinued. I believe that the Minister for Repatriation is as anxious as any one can be that every facility shall be afforded to our soldiers to re-establish themselves on their return. These matters are of considerable importance to the returned soldiers. An allowance of £25 is a substantial allowance for commencing housekeeping in a small way. I hope that the deductions in allowances previously given, to which I have referred, will be restored.

With regard to the amendment;, I am not aware whether in the case of a fund established under the authority of the Repatriation Department it is competent for the managers of the fund to raise money for the insurance of the lives of soldiers. I should like the Minister to look into the matter?

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator means, for instance, such a fund as exists in Adelaide?

- Yes, the Soldiers' Fund. I wish to know whether it is competent for the managers of that fund, under the auspices of the Repatriation authorities, to invite public subscriptions in order,, as is proposed in South Australia, to provide an insurance of £100, in each case, for the benefit of relatives of soldiers who have fallen nr. the Front, lt is proposed that the scheme shall be made retrospective, and shall apply in the case of all soldiers who have fallen, from the commencement of the war.
- Does the honorable senator say that it is intended to raise the whole of the money necessary to give effect to such a proposal?

- Those concerned desire to be in a position to pay from £75 to £125 in respect of every deceased soldier from South Australia who had relatives dependent upon him. I am not criticising the scheme, but asking the Minister for guidance, in order that those who have proposed it may know the position in which they will be placed. I might add, as one who has taken considerable interest in recruiting, that I am anxious to know whether, when I go upon a recruiting platform, I shall be justified in inducing recruits to join up by telling them that such a scheme as I have referred to is feasible, and has the approval of the Repatriation* authorities. I should like to have been in a position to put the matter privately to the Minister, because I could then say many things which the Chairman of Committees will not permit me to say here.
-. - The honorable member would say more to me than he can say to the Chairman.

- Yes, because the Chairman of Committees has an awkward way of keeping honorable senators to the point - though I must say that I have no reason to complain this afternoon. I again direct the attention of the Minister to the points I have raised. T think we are all animated by the desire to make the repatriation scheme as just and as generous as we possibly can.

. - There is one matter to which I wish the Minister for Repatriation (Senator Millen) would give some consideration. Throughout the Bill the words " sailor or soldier " are used. The sailor is virtually the man on deck. The term does not cover men below - such as the engineer, the stoker, or the steward. I should like the Minister to consider the advisability of substituting the word " seamen" for the word "sailor" in the Bill. The word "seaman " would cover every one on board the ship.

- The definition of persons benefiting under the Act includes " any one serving, or who has served, during the present war in the Naval or Military Forces." The men to whom Senator Guthrie has referred are certainly serving.
- It would be far better to use the word " seaman " instead of the word " sailor,"' as that would bring

speech.para: Hie phraseology into harmony with our merchant shipping law. I commend the suggestion to the Minister when reconsidering the clause which we have postponed.
Senator MILLEN (New South Wales-

quote.para: Minister for Repatriation) [3.59]. - If I thought it at all necessary I should willingly adopt the suggestion put forward by Senator Guthrie. If it had been made when the Bill was being drafted there might have been much to commend its adoption, but it is not now competent for us to alter the interpretation clause, and to use a different term in one clause would make the different interpretation applicable only to that clause.

talk.start.para: - I mean that the word " seaman " should be used throughout the Bill.

- If Senator Guthrie will turn to the definition section of the original Act he will find that any person is deemed to be an Australian soldier within the meaning of the Act who - is or has been during the present war a member of the Naval or Military Forces, enlisted or appointed, for, or employed on active service outside Australia, or employed on a Mp of war. t submit that that is sufficiently wide to include all the persons to whom Senator Guthrie- has referred.
- The use of the word " sailor " is wrong. A stoker is not a sailor:
- He is serving in the Naval Forces.
- An engineer is not ;i sailor.

- But the measure will apply not only to a sailor, but to tuy one who has served or who is serving. I do not know that I can add any more to what I have said, but I give Senator Guthrie the assurance that I am perfectly satisfied that the definition includes all to whom he has referred. I will undertake that if it is found in the administration of the Act that for nome reason or another it does not, I shall immediately, by administration, include such persons as Senator Guthrie has referred to, and come later to Parliament for the necessary amendment of the law. I would not allow a technicality to deny to any member of the Naval or Military Forces a right which Parliament intended he should have.
- The honorable senator will not always be Minister for Repatriation.
- I feel sure that any Minister administering the Act will take that view.

speech.para: With regard to some of the matters raised by Senator Newland, the honorable senator appeared himself to be conscious that they did not quite come within the scope of the amendment. I do not know anything of the constitution of the fund to which he referred, or the purposes for which it was raised, so I cannot express a definite opinion on that point, but I shall be glad to have a chat with the honorable senator on the .subject later on. He was not quite right in saying that the furniture grant has been abolished. It has not, but the conditions of the grant have been altered. Originally it was granted in such a way that every returned man seemed to think that he had a right to it, and' many to whom it was of no benefit as an aid to setting them up again in life, and some who did not want it, claimed it and got it. The principle governing its allotment now is that it shall be granted only in those cases where the purpose is to re-establish a man in civil life. I think that that is a principle which has much to commend it.

talk.start.para: - It has been refused in several cases that I know of.

- That may be so. The revised regulation was passed within the last fortnight, and the principle now adopted may not yet be fully known. Under the new principle, wherever a grant for furniture will help a returned man to establish a home, or, it may be, to accept a situation, it will be made, but it will not be granted merely because it i3 claimed.

speech.para: With respect to the matter of housing, I have only to remind honorable senators that there are many difficulties in the way of proposing a general housing scheme, to say nothing of the enormous cost involved. The difficulties are so great that the Repatriation Commission did not feel that they were ready to launch a general scheme at the same time as the regulations were put forward.

talk.start.para: - The grants are only loans.

- That is so. I hope before long to be able to put forward a complete scheme. When honorable senators realize that the majority of the returned men would possibly become applicants under any generous housing scheme, they will see at once the tremendous financial responsibility involved. I may feel justified in asking Parliament to make the necessary provision to meet a reasonable and sound scheme, and one that will be fairly generous to the returned soldiers. But it is not easy to link the two things together.

- Many men who. after their return, were detained in hospitals for months, missed their opportunity to take advantage of the allowance provided, while men who returned only recently in fairly sound health have had the benefit of the advances.

- It is quite true that those who have returned since the new system was introduced will, in some cases, miss benefits that previously existed, whilst they will secure benefits which previously did not exist.
- Some men who returned before the alteration of the system were too ill to take advantage of it.

- I may inform the honorable senator that no man whose application was in before the new system was proposed was turned down. His application is treated as though it were 5760 Australian Soldiers' [SENATE.] Repatriation Bill (No. 2). matured before the new system was brought into vogue. The matter is one which interests us all, and perhaps on that account I have been tempted to speak longer than I intended. I assure honorable senators that I appreciate the various suggestions that have been made, but I will have the sympathy of the Committee when I say that unless we want the whole scheme to break down, we must avoid incurring expenditure that may do no real good to the returned soldier.

item.para: A report of the operations under the Australian Soldiers' Repatriation Act shall be furnished annually."

speech.para: Motion (by Senator Millen) proposed -

quote.para: That the amendment be agreed to.

talk.start.para: . - I think we should agree to this amendment, because it provides that Parliament should be annually furnished with a report of the work done by the Commission. I do not know how many persons are already employed on the staff of the Repatriation Department, nor do I know how many more it is contemplated employing. But evidently the Department is going to be a very big one. We already have a Minister whose attention is devoted almost exclusively to the Department, and as more of our soldiers return to Australia we may expect that the staff of the Department will increase very materially. I should like this annual report to contain a statement showing what has been done in the way of land" settlement. We hear a good deal of talk

speech.para: Australian Soldiers' [12 June, 1918.] Repatriation Bill (No. 2). 5761 about the work that is being accomplished by the various State Governments and by the various Local Committees. But only the other day we were confronted in Melbourne with a. deputation consisting of 500 or 600 returned soldiers who assured us that they were out of work and were unable to procure employment.

talk.start.para: - When was that?

- About three weeks ago. Statements of the same character have appeared in the Sydney press. I think that the annual report should disclose exactly what is being done, not only in the way of finding employment in our secondary industries for returned soldiers, but what is being done in the direction of settling any of them permanently on the lands of this country.
- I think the honorable senator may take it for granted that that information will be supplied.

- I do not know. Official reports very often neglect to take cognisance of the most important matters. 1 would like to see a statement in the annual report of the estates which have been purchased by the Government, the prices paid for them, and their valuation for taxation purposes.
- Order ! The honorable senator is getting rather wide of the question that is before the Chair.

- I certainly wish to see a complete report of the lands which have been purchased, and of the prices which have been paid for them. It is not fair to attempt to settle returned soldiers on land that has been purchased at fictitious prices.
- Order ! That matter is quite outside the scope of the amendment. The honorable senator will have an opportunity of discussing it later on.
- Then I shall avail myself of that opportunity.

. - I think that Senator Grant may possess his soul in patience. He may be perfectly certain that in an annual report presented to Parliament a responsible Department will endeavour to cover the whole field of its operations. When the first report is presented, Senator Grant will doubtless be here, and will then be able to take exception to any omissions from it.

talk.start.para: . - I move -

quote.para: That the amendment be agreed to with the following addition : - "and (iv) the incapacitated fathers of deceased or incapacitated Australian soldiers who were prior to the enlistment of those soldiers, dependent upon them."

talk.start.para: - Cannot the Minister omit the latter portion of that paragraph ?

-I cannot. That is the very danger which I fear. If it were possible to do it, I would have no objection to the insertion of a simple clause in the Bill which would give everybody everything they ask.
- Every deserving person.
- But that raises the question of who is a deserving person.
- That is easily settled.

- It is when an honorable senator is sitting on the other side of the chamber. But we have only to consider the experience of America in connexion with its pension bill to sec the evil that has to be guarded against. Today America has a bigger pension bill than she had when the Civil War terminated. My proposal represents a very fair effort to meet those cases which stand out as clearly entitled to consideration. I ask the Committee, therefore, to accept it. If, in the light of experience, it is 'found necessary to widen the Act, it will be easy to do so. It will be easier to widen it, as the result of experience, than it will be to close down upon applicants later on.

. - The injustice which will be inflicted by the latter portion of the Minister's proposal is so obvious that I cannot understand his attitude. Take the case of a father who is in a really good position to-day, and whose son makes the supreme sacrifice. A few years hence that father may experience a reversal of fortune, as the result o'f which he may be left in his declining years without the son who would have been his support. Yet he will be prevented from getting any assistance under this Bill. Thus the door will be closed to perhaps the most deserving cases which could be dealt with. Such cases will not be few, but many. Take the case of a man who has made the education of his sons his chief object in life. He may have made no provision for himself. His sons may be killed on the battlefield, and, perhaps, ten years hence, when he is in declining health, he may be urgently in need of support, but will be unable to get it.
- It is a question of responsibility.

- I would put the responsibility on the Minister. If we say that a father who is not now dependent upon his sons, but -who ten years hence may require support, shall receive no consideration, we shall be treating wealth very differently from the way in which we are treating manhood. I move -

quote.para: That the amendment be farther amended by adding the following words to the proposed addition: - "Provided that nothing in this Act shall prevent the Minister from dealing with every case of hardship, and giving relief to either the parents or dependants of any soldier."

talk.start.para: . - The amendment is one which, in a general sense, will appeal to everybody's sympathies. But what does it amount to ? It seeks to throw on the Minister the responsibility of accepting or refusing every application made by anybody who can prove that he has suffered in the remotest degree, either now or twenty years hence. If Parliament wishes to do that, it ought not to throw the responsibility on the Minister. It ought to say, by means of a schedule, what it proposes to do. That would make the thing comparatively easy of administration, but to throw ou the Minister or the Department the responsibility of determining the degree of* relationship, dependency, or hardship, and the bona fides of the case, without some indication of what Parliament wants, is asking altogether too much. If the honorable senator represents any considerable body of opinion here, the way to give effect to it is, not by such a general, vague resolution as this, but by specific proposals in the direction of a new and wider Bill, which will set out with considerable particularity what is desired. I should shrink from administering a clause of that kind, and I ask the Committee to negative the proposition, not as an indication of want of sympathy with deserving cases, but because of its impracticability.

. - I realize that it is difficult to devise a clause to meet all the conditions that may arise. I have been trusting to the Minister for Repatriation (Senator Millen) and the Government to make ample provision for all the dependants of soldiers -who will be left in poverty because of the fact that men have died fighting for us. It reads very well for the Minister to tell me to introduce a new Bill, but honorable senators know that a private member has no hope of getting a Bill through, particularly when he is in a minority of two to one. In every Bill that has come before us we have provided for an ample return to the man who puts money into the war, but we shrink from the cost of making an adequate return to those who have put their lives into the war. It is pleaded that we should not saddle the Minister with responsibility. If I were the Minister administering the Act ten years' hence, and a man who is now well off came to me in reduced circumstances, caused through losing his two sons at the war, I would not shrink from doing my best to help him. It is a big thing to repatriate our soldiers; but I have had experience of the hardships that occur under the Old-age Pensions Act. The most deserving cases are shut out from relief because of the wording of that Act. and are struggling along under conditions that are a disgrace to our civiliza-

speech.para: Australian Soldiers' [12 June, 1918.] Repatriation Bill (No. 2). 5763 tion. Minister after Minister has admitted, and Under-Secretaries have admitted, that that is so; but they are powerless to go beyond the Act, and it must be remembered that Under-Secretaries are more careful than . Ministers, because they have the continuous responsibility of administering the Act, while Ministers come and go. I want to avoid, so far as our soldiers are concerned, the state of tilings that has occurred under the Old-age Pensions Act. I am not wedded to the amendment, which I wrote out hastily, but it is wide enough to give the Minister an opportunity to relieve every deserving case.

talk.start.para: - What is your standard of "deserving"?

- I would be prepared to say that a deserving case was one in want owing to the fact that a son had died or had been incapacitated lighting for us. I would go so far as to say that the want must be directly attributable to the sacrifice of the son. Here and now we have a chance to open the gate to deserving cases, but the Minister proposes to shut them out for fear that undeserving cases may get through. He may do so if he wishes, but I shall press the amendment to give the Committee the opportunity to do the right thing.

. - I support Senator Gardiner's amendment, of which the very vagueness and openness please me. I should like to see something like it in all our pensions and charitable laws. An old boilermaker whom I served my time with came to see me the other day. He had got the old-age pension, but it was not enough to keep him, so he went out rabbit-trapping and earned a few pounds. The result was that his pension was stopped, because he had earned more during the year than he was entitled to under the Act. The official administering the Act wants to help him, but cannot do so, because that is the law. The law has him tied down, and my contention is that the law should be open enough to avoid hardships of that kind. The man is now stranded in Sydney. These are the cases we have to look to, and, therefore, I shall support a wide proposal such as Senator Gardiner has put before us.
. - Senator Gardiner's amendment is not within the scope of the clause. His amendment is general, and the clause deals only with specific cases.

quote.para: Senate's Amendment. - " At end of paragraph (f) add the following new sub-paragraph: -

item.para: gifts exceeding twenty-one shillings each to public charitable institutions in Australia, if the gifts are verified to the satisfaction of the Commissioner."

quote.para: House of Representatives' Message. - Amendment amended by the omission of the words "twenty-one shillings," and by the insertion of the words " Five pounds " in place thereof.

debate.para: Committee will remember that when this Bill was under consideration previously a sub-paragraph was inserted providing that gifts of 21s. and upwards to the public charitable institutions of Australia should be exempt from income tax. It was pointed out in the other House, however, that it would be extremely difficult to trace and identify such small donations, and that at the same time where amounts were so small the remission to the taxpayers would be comparatively negligible. The House of Representatives, therefore, amended the provision by striking out the words " twenty-one shillings " and inserting " Five pounds." I move -

quote.para: That the amendment be agreed to.

talk.start.para: . - I am rather in favour of the amendment inserted by the House of Representatives, though I am sorry to see even £5 mentioned as the amount of exemption, because, so far as concerns donations to public charities or patriotic funds, I would prefer no exemption at all. People give to these funds from philanthropic or patriotic motives, and it seems strange that we should insert a provision granting exemption from income tax payments in respect of such donations. I think that when the Committee of the Senate fixed the amount at 21s. there was some slight misunderstanding as to the manner in which the amount should be calculated.

. - I think the purpose of the amendment moved by Senator O'Loghlin, fixing the amount at £1ls., was that the exemption should refer to an accumulation of such gifts, that it should refer to a number of donations of £1ls. to any of the institutes referred to. I should like to know from the Minister if the amount is to be calculated in that way, or if the amendment refers to single donations.

. - Gifts of that amount would -not be recognised, because of the difficulty in tracing them. We all know that people give small amounts to various public institutions; but it would be extremely difficult for them to demonstrate that they had made these gifts in order to secure exemption from income tax.

speech.para: Income Tax [12 June, 1918.] Assessment Bill. 5765

talk.start.para: - Then I think we ought to wipe the clause out altogether.
- There may be something in that view; but I ask the Committee to recognise the practical impossibility of identifying small amounts of £11s.

. - I am rather surprised to hear what the Minister has said. I understand, now, that if a person gives £50 in gifts of £1 each to a charitable institution, he will be granted no exemption from income tax in respect of the total : whereas, if a person gives £5 in any single gift, he will be entitled to exemption. That is rather unfortunate, and I shall be glad to vote against the proposal.

. - I think we should strike it out altogether. I realize, with Senator Millen, the difficulty of tracing gifts, and that the real benefit to the taxpayer by way of remission of taxation will not be very much. If the striking out of the provision results in a curtailment of donations to the institutions referred to, then we should still have power to make up any deficiency by way of direct taxation. The Minister will be well advised to strike out the provision altogether. I do not want to stress this question of unfairness in dealing with different classes of the community; but I point out that a gift of £11s. is a large amount for a man with a family to maintain on the wages of an ordinary tradesman, whereas a gift of £5 5s. would not be much to a man like, say- Senator Pratten. I do not wish the honorable senator to think that I am making an unfair comparison. I am merely quoting his position as compared with mine. If we both were out of the Senate to-morrow, £5 would not be very much to him ;. whereas, £11s. might be a great deal to me. Income taxation is down amongst the poorer people in the community to-day; and if we are not going to grant exemption in respect of gifts of £11s., while we propose to grant exemption to a man who can afford to donate £5 to a charitable institution, that is a form of class distinction which I shall not support.

. - In the original Act there was provision granting exemption in respect of gifts exceeding £20, and when that was struck out in another place, and the measure came before the Senate, it was thought that it would tell very hardly probably on some institutions, if some provision were not made in respect of gifts to those institutions. At times, large gifts come to our hospitals, and it was felt to be inequitable if a heavy amount of income taxation was also levied upon large donors. When this clause was under review, it was felt, too, I think, that if it was fair to make deductions in respect of contributions for repatriation and other similar patriotic purposes, it was also fair to make deductions in respect of contributions to hospitals and similar institutions. I think it would be distinctly unfair to these institutions to strike out the clause altogether ; because they are not included in the clause granting remission of income taxation in respect of donations to repatriation and other patriotic objects. While I appreciate the Very vivid illustration given by Senator Gardiner, I think it is hardly worth while, and, indeed it is almost ridiculous, to insert a clause exempting donations of one guinea because the taxation on those amounts would be only a few shillings. The real reason for the incorporation by the Senate of the provision in the Bill was to cover big donations to institutions that were not provided for in the other clause to which I have already referred. I think a reasonable compromise has been made in another place by inserting the words " Five pounds " instead of "twenty-one shillings " - a compromise as between £20, as originally provided, and one guinea, as passed by the Committee of the Senate. I hope my honorable friends opposite will consider carefully the effect of striking out this provision, because it will have a considerable influence on very large donations to deserving institutions throughout the Commonwealth.
. - I intend to move -

quote.para: That sub-paragraph (iii) of paragraph / be left out.

speech.para: After the remarks made by the financial expert of the Senate (Senator Pratten), I feel more convinced than ever that I am right in asking the Committee to strike out the provision altogether. Senator Pratten laid stress on the fact that, if exemption is not granted, donations to the institutions referred to may be affected, but I do not think this will trouble some of the wealthy people very much. A mistake seems to have been made with regard to this clause. Senator Fairbairn first moved that the amount should be £20. Then he was induced to alter it to £1 ; and after that he wanted it back to £20 again. Then when Senator O'Loghlin moved that the sum should be 21s., that amendment was agreed to without any honorable senator really understanding the whole of the facts. I am pleased now that Senator Pratten has given reasons why I should move that the whole matter be struck out. The difficulty and trouble of having to supply proof to the Taxation Commissioner will be considerable, while the benefit to be gained by the individual will be relatively trifling.
Motion, by leave, withdrawn.
Motion (by Senator McDougall) proposed -

quote.para: That the Committee disagrees to the amendment of the House of Representatives, and does not insist on its own amendment.

talk.start.para: . - I hope the Committee will not be led into a serious blunder. The near future will prove that very great efforts will be required on the part of the public to provide sufficient funds for dealing with repatriation. We should not place any possible obstacle in the way of donations. Take the case of a rich man who desires to leave a large share of his wealth to the Repatriation Fund,, and has provided to that effect in his will. After his death it would mean a very serious item to have to pay income tax out of the estate without any remission in respect of the generous donation. Does it strike honorable senators as quite fair that, while on the one hand the authorities may be accepting a very large gift for the repatriation scheme, the Commissioner of Taxation, on the other, may require a very heavy payment of income tax out of the estate, without any remission? Such a situation might well discourage the making of bequests of that nature.

. - The specific purpose of the Senate in its amendment under review was that contributions other than to the Repatriation Department or to various patriotic funds, should also be included in the exemptions- from payment of income tax. The Bill already provides for remission of income taxation in connexion with payments made during the continuance of the war to any patriotic fund for any purpose connected with the war, " if the payments are verified to the satisfaction of the Commissioner." It also provides for exemptions and remissions in the case of contributions to the Department of Repatriation, " provided that the value of the contribution shall be verified to the satisfaction of the Commissioner." The Committee is now dealing with an addition which, if incorporated in the Bill as proposed by the Minister, will permit of remission in connexion with contributions to hospitals and other benevolent institutions.

speech.para: If the amendment of Senator McDougall is carried it will only mean the striking out of the words which were previously inserted in the Senate, and will not affect exemptions already given under the Bill. I wish it to be clear, therefore, that in rejecting the subparagraph in question, we will not do away with remissions in connexion with contributions to the Repatriation Department and to patriotic funds. We shall only be cutting out exemptions upon contributions to philanthropic institutions. We shall be placing a handicap upon hospitals, and that will be an invidious distinction.

talk.start.para: - Do you think any man would withhold his subscription to a hospital for that reason?

- It is an extremely inconsistent course to grant remission in one case and not in the other, and for that reason I shall vote for the amendment as it stands. If honorable senators would say that they were not prepared to give exemptions of any kind I could understand their attitude; but the point is that that principle could not be asserted at this stage in dealing with. the measure.

. - I am glad Senator Pratten concluded in the way he did. The Senate inserted an amendment that exemptions should bc granted upon any gifts amounting to 21s. Another place has raised the amount to £5. That makes it merely a matter of granting remission either upon a small gift or upon one which is- a little larger; but the inconsistency is that a man would get no remission of income tax if he contributed £.1 a. week all the year round, whereas he

speech.para: Income Tax [12 June, 1918.] Assessment Bill. 5767 could secure exemption if he gave only the one lamp sum of £5.

Take the case of the tramway men of Sydney. They taxed themselves voluntarily to the extent, I believe, of10 per cent. of their income. The money largely went to the purchase of material for making various things for the military hospitals. That good course was continued until the men went out on strike. Of course, the loyalists now will not do anything like that. "Week after week the old unionists paid their money in as regularly as though they were adding to their banking accounts. They got no remission upon their payments. If remission may be had upon gifts of 21s. that will affect a great number of people, while if the amount, is raised to £5 there will be comparatively few who will be able to take advantage of the exemption. Some honorable senators say that the withholding of any exemption will have its effect upon large contributions. There are many rich folk who, out of the goodness of their hearts, give large donations and do not consider whether they may receive remission of taxation.

As for the argument of Senator de Largie, that wealthy people may be discouraged from making bequests under their wills, that reminds me of an article which I read in a certain Sydney newspaper, dealing with Senator Pearce, in which the writer incidentally mentioned that Senator de Largie was the dullest man in the Senate. As a matter of fact, that writer could not have been in this chamber since either Senator Earle or Senator Plain arrived, or he would never have "written in a manner so grossly unjust to Senator de Largie.

talk.start.para: - What has this to do with the Bill?

- . Nothing. Probably it is only the old feud between us. Senator de Largie said, in effect, that we should not inflict injustice upon those who have passed away. Honorable senators should consider the great amount of trouble that will be caused in the Taxation Department in verifying all claims for exemption : and then they should remember how little the amount of remission will total.I shall vote that the sub-paragraph be struck out, because it makes an invidious distinction, and is unjust.
- Provision might be made in the Bill as it stands for donations of £1 per week.

- I do not want such a provision. I do not think it would be worth anything. I do not believe that there is any demand for exemption from income tax in respect of these donations. The man who gives £1,000 to any -of these funds does not care whether he will secure exemption from income tax because of it or not. He makes his donation because his heart is in the business, and the fact that he will be exempt from income tax in respect to the amount of his subscription is not an incentive to him to give it, and the abolition of such a provision would not prevent him from contributing to these funds. The provision exemplifies, in an objectionable manner, the difference between the way in which we treat the wealthy and the rest of the community. If we make an allowance by our legislation for the man who gives a large amount, we should make an equal allowance for the man who gives a small amount. One man may give a small amount frequently, while another, because it may be of some importance to him, may give a large sum very occasionally. This provision makes an invidious distinction between those who can afford to give largely, and those who cannot.
- If we apply the provision to a donation of £1, some persons might give 5s. per week.
- I quite agree with the honorable senator. I am not supporting the application of the provision to donations of £1. I am prepared to vote to wipe out the whole thing.
- What does the honorable senator intend to support; the striking out of the provision altogether, or agreement with the proposal carried here?

- I support the striking out of the provision altogether. We should not tolerate these invidious distinctions. I object to provisions in our legislation intended to appeal to certain persons, and to make it appear that we are specially considering them. Our legislation should do what it purports 'to do. Special provision to give relief to certain persons, and to meet special cases, will always fail. We can only safely legislate in a general way, realizing that our legislation should apply equally to the whole of the people.
- Is the honorable senator going to exempt donations to patriotic funds, and not to hospitals ?
- If the provision dealt with patriotic funds, I should deal with it in exactly the same way.
- But we have already passed the other provision.
- In my opinion it should not have been passed. But now that our attention is drawn to the matter, and we are able to deal with it, we should decide that this kind of thing shall cease.
- Two wrongs do not make a right.

- Because we have done one wrong, we should not therefore tlo another. As a matter of fact, two wrongs do sometiir.es make a right. If I gave the honorable senator a bad shilling, that would be a wrong, but if he gave it to Senator Thomas, while it would" be a wrong, it would make him right. So that it may be argued that two wrongs sometimes make one right. The objectionable feature of this provision is that it marks in our legislation class distinctions. It holds out an exemption of income tax to those who can afford to give large sums, and honorable members in another place seem to have deliberately, by their proposal, shut out from the same consideration those who cannot afford to do so. Because of this distinction I shall vote against the motion.

. - In my view it is unfortunate that we should have proceeded so far as we have done with this invidious system of taxation. This is a part of the punishment which must be inflicted, not only upon the members of the Committee, but upon the public generally, because of the methods adopted for raising national revenue. We are now asked to exempt from income tax donations which goodhearted people are prepared to give to hospitals. I think it is a very good idea to exempt such donations, because I believe that from stem to stern the income tax law is upon a wrong basis, and should bo repealed as soon as possible.
- I ask the honorable senator to keep to the amendment, and not to discuss the income tax generally.
- This proposal is one which meets with my approval, because it limits the amount of taxation which can be derived under this Bill.
- What would the honorable senator put in its place?
- A straight-out land value tax.
- The honorable senator will not be in order in discussing a land value tax.

- My remark was entirely due to the disorderly interjection of Senator de Largie, who seems to have forgotten the taxation principles which guided his early youth, and to have wandered away into this mil de sac for national taxation. The proposal made in another place did not, in my opinion, receive the attention there which it should have received. It has been proposed that gifts exceeding 21s. to public charities may be deducted from the amount upon which the taxpayer has to pay. It would have been better if it had been suggested that the deduction should apply to " gifts of or exceeding 21s." As the amendment; stands a person would require to give 21s. Id. to secure the proposed exemption. This illustrates the absurdity of the proposal. Merely on the ground that it will reduce the sources from which income taxation may be derived, I am prepared to support the proposal.

. - The arguments put forward by Senator Gardiner are incontestable. There can be no doubt that if we accept the amendment of the House of Representatives we shall institute a class distinction under this Bill. It is well known that during the war the citizens of Australia have contributed generously in response to appeals for hospitals, Red Cross, and other patriotic and charitable purposes. I venture to say that many men in receipt of very small wages have contributed an average of between £10 and £12 a year to various charitable movements. They will continue to make further contributions in the future. Under this amendment a man who gives 2s. to a fund to-day and 3s. to-morrow, though his contributions in the course of a year may amount to £10 or £12, will receive no exemption from income tas

speech.para: Income Tax[ 12 June. 1918.] Assessment Bill. 5769 in respect of those payments, whilst the man who is in a position to give £5 in one sum is at once entitled to exemption. The Minister in charge of the Bill (Senator Millen) made no reply to the practical suggestion by Senator McDougall to make the provision apply cumulatively to donations of 21s., so that if any person gave 21s. weekly to a public charitable institution, he might secure exemption in respect of the total amount he contributed during the year in that way. As to the position arising in connexion with a contribution of £5 as against a contribution of £11s., Senator de Largie was apprehensive that the provision might interfere with contributions to the Repatriation Fund, but Senator Pratten has pointed out that that is provided for. If the Committee accepts the amendment moved by Senator McDougall, no charitable institution in Australia will suffer. No man in the habit of giving a donation to a hospital will cease to do so because the amount will not be deducted from the amount upon which he will have to pay income tax.

talk.start.para: - But we shall be giving a premium to other contributions.
- I do not think so. There is a vast difference between a patriotic fund and a charitable institution.
- This is not only patriotic, but charitable also.

- It is charitable in the first instance, because long before the war broke out people were in the habit of making contributions to hospitals. The word " patriotic " has been introduced since the outbreak of the war, and it is very often misapplied in this connexion. I fail to see how Senator de Largie can suggest that the Repatriation Department should be regarded as a charitable institution. This clause deals with public charitable institutions, and no honorable senator will dare to say that the Repatriation Department is a charitable institution.
- It is both charitable and patriotic.
- Repatriation is the duty of the nation.
- I direct the honorable senator's attention to the fact that we are not discussing repatriation.
- I am replying to the statement made by Senator de Largie, who appeared to think that the Repatriation Fund would be injured if the amendment were carried.
- The honorable senator is endeavouring to put a stigma on charity.

- It is impossible to put a stigma on charity. The honorable senator, no doubt, unintentionally suggested that the Repatriation Department is a charitable institution, but it is the duty of the nation to look after repatriation. It should be provided for whether gifts are made to the Repatriation Fund or not. If any one desires to make a donation to the fund, it will naturally be accepted, but the work of repatriation should not depend on any donation, and the fund should be provided in the fulfilment of a national duty. The Committee will be acting wisely in agreeing to. the amendment moved by Senator McDougall.

division.header.para: Question - That the Committee disagrees to the amendment of the House of Representatives, and does not insist on its own amendment (Senator McDougall's motion) - put. The Committee divided.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

division.para: Motion negatived. 5770 Income Tax [SENATE.] Assessment Bill.

division.header.para: Motion (by Senator Millen) - That the amendment be agreed to - put. The Committee divided.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

quote.para: Section 57 of the principal Act is amended by inserting before the word "Fifty" the words "not less than Five pounds nor more than."
Senate's amendment - Leave out the clause.
House of Representatives' Message - Amendment not agreed to, but clause amended by leaving out " Five pounds " and by inserting " One pound" in lieu thereof.

talk.start.para: . - This is one of a number of amendments in which, departing from the practice which has previously obtained in our legislative enactments, the other House has inserted a minimum as well as a maximum penalty. I am not at all certain that I was not one of those who suggested the advisableness of keeping this measure in conformity with all the other enactments of this Parliament. However, the Bill has come back from the House of Representatives with an amendment giving a reason why a minimum as well as a maximum penalty should be adhered to. That reason is that magistrates throughout Australia take such widely different views of the same offence. In some cases the magistrates inflict a fine of a few shillings for an offence for which other magistrates mulct an offender in a fine of some pounds. In these circumstances it has been thought better that Parliament should indicate for the guidance of magistrates the minimum penalty which should be inflicted for a given offence. I move -

quote.para: That the Committee does not insist on its amendment and agrees to that of the House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: . - This amendment seems to me to open up a very wide field because what will apply to this Bill will apply also to Acts which have been passed by this Parliament - Acts in which a maximum penalty has been prescribed. The reason advanced by the other branch of the Legislature for the proposed amendment is, to my mind, insufficient. It might just as well be argued that a magistrate should be compelled to inflict either the minimum or the maximum penalty.
- There are qualifying words.

- Hitherto in our legislation the maximum penalty, and not the minimum, has been inserted. To my mind, it is a wise plan to provide for a maximum penalty alone. But under this one man may be fined £2 and another man £10for the same offence. I do not think we are acting wisely in departing from the custom which has hitherto obtained. Hitherto our Federal Statutes have been remarkable for their clearness and uniformity.
- Not too much clearness.

- I have many times heard it remarked by those who are accustomed to deal with Statutes that our Federal Acts are very much clearer than are the State Acts. In the early days of the Federation this was especially the case. In the present instance we are asked to depart from a very wise precedent. This is scarcely the measure in which we should institute such a departure, even if it be necessary.

. - The particular amendment now before us deals with clause 38 of the Bill. The Senate struck out the clause in its entirety. In another place the provision has been re-inserted, with an amendment substituting £1 for £5. The clause deals with penalties, and if we agree to the

speech.para: Income Tax,[12 June, 1918.] Assessment Bill. 5771 amendment which we are now considering the clause will read -

quote.para: Section57 of the principal Act is amended by inserting before the word " Fifty " the words " net less than One pound nor more than ".

talk.start.para: . - Senator Senior appeals to me when he argues that this is exceptional legislation and that we are getting away from the fine old principle which has worked so well hitherto. We all know of cases where a person is technically guilty, and where the magistrate has expressed his sorrow that he has had to inflict a penalty, although there has been no real offence. Power should be left to a magistrate where only a technical breach of the taw has been committed to impose a nominal fine of, say,1s. We should refuse to break away from the old principle of fixing the maximum and allowing the magistrate to say what the minimum shall be. Many cases may arise in which a fine of £1 is exorbitant. True justice demands that the penalty shall be commensurate with the offence, and if we insist upon a penalty that is out of proportion to the offence, people will become dissatisfied with our Courts of justice. I shall adhere to our previous decision to wipe out the minimum penalty. One pound is a considerable amount of money to a great many people, though it may seem nothing to those who are accustomed to handling thousands. To leave the minimum to the discretion of the magistrate is safe, satisfactory, and in accord with all our previous legislation.
. - Those who drafted the original Income Tax Act worded section 57 in this way, no doubt for very good reasons -

quote.para: Any person who obstructs or hinders an officer acting in the discharge of his duty under this Act or the regulations shall be guilty of an offence. Penalty : £50.

speech.para: The Minister now assures us that under the Acts Interpretation Act £50 may mean only1s. To honorable senators who, on the advice of Ministers, are prepared to vote millions of pounds in a few hours, it may seem a very small matter whether the fine is£1 or £50, but, to the person who has to pay it, it may mean a great deal more than he can rake up. Surely we can rely on. the magistrates to exercise their judgment and impose a fine commensurate with the offence.

talk.start.para: -Colonel O'LOGHLIN (South Australia) [5.41]. - The Minister (Senator Millen) has not made out a very good case for abolishing the minimum. He advanced the reason that there is a wide variation in the decisions of magistrates'. That is probably because there is a wide variation in the cases that come before them, but this proposal does not prevent that variation, because the fines may still vary from £1 up to £50. All it does is to prevent them going below £1. There may be many cases of nominal offences where no penalty is really deserved, and the magistrate should have power to inflict a nominal fine. Senator Senior has put forward the good old Conservative rule, which particularly appeals to us on this side that we should observe the wisdom- of our forefathers, who decided that there should be no minimum., but that vindictive penalties should be prevented by the inclusion of a maximum.

division.header.para: Question - That the Committee does not insist on its amendment, and agrees to that of the House of Representatives - put. The Committee divided.
